Description: Egyptian sealing in fired clay. A sealing from a document, impressed from a large circular seal bearing the almost front facing bust of a beardless man with short hair, possibly a portrait, perhaps of a Julio-Claudian. On the left shoulder is an obscure object (a brooch?) with the appearance of a gorgoneion or a lion’s head. The back has an impression of the papyrus document to which it was attached, with a hole for the string that bound the package. Red-brown Nile silt with a little mica and many white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Found with BM1886,0401.1701 and 1702. Petrie dates this group as 2nd century AD (Petrie 1886, 100, pl. XX nos 20-22). Clay resembles local Naukratis red Nile silt fabric, but could have been sent here from another location on the Nile Delta. '1' in pencil on inside.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3620)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 100, pl. XX, no. 21)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (PB.09)
Condition: Clay is very fragile and cracked.
